title: Instructor Guide — ASL 1.1 Fingerspelling A–Z
objectives: Coach recognition and production of ASL letters A–Z with correct handshape and palm orientation
Facilitate learners fingerspelling their first/last name and 3 domain words (school/tech/career)
Build fluency through chunking (A–M, N–Z) and smooth transitions (no mouthing)

Common Core.SL.9-10.1: Structured partner drills; accountable talk in signed modality
Common Core.SL.9-10.6: Adapts signing clarity and speed to audience

ISTE.1.6: Creates and shares signed content for authentic audiences

CSTA.1A-CS-01: Represents data (letters) with symbols and precision

IDEA.A11y: Provides visual, tactile, and pacing scaffolds for diverse learners

pacing.activity: Silent greet + posture check; show alphabet poster (fade quickly)
Model A–M slowly (front/side angle). Class mirrors. Emphasize palm orientation
Model N–Z. Quick contrast for M vs N; Q vs G; dominant-hand rule
Partner drill: A spells name (2×), B gives one cue (palm/handshape). Swap
Tech words (pick 3): APP, CODE, EMAIL, DATA, AI. Chunk by syllables for flow
Quick check: 5 random letters call-and-response; fix high-frequency errors
Exit ticket: 10–15s video — first name + one tech word; upload to portfolio

roomSetup: Pairs facing each other; sightlines to instructor’s face maintained

prep: Print or load alphabet slide; prepare 3–4 example tech words
Open the arcade links for fast transitions
Set up portfolio upload instructions (QR or LMS link)

IEP_504: Offer seated mirroring with side-angle demo
Provide handshape cue cards; allow slower pace and extra reps
ELL: Bridge to English letter names briefly, then fade
Use picture cards for tech words to reduce cognitive load
Advanced: Timed A–Z sprint with accuracy threshold
Spell two-word phrases; add common first/last names
DeafBlind_futureReady: Tactile demo (instructor/peer) for a few high-contrast letters
Verbalize handshape descriptions for aide training
UDL: Clear rule posters: Orientation > Speed; Face > Hands

teachingNotes.guidance: Model compact signing at torso; avoid big arcs. Emphasize face visibility; remind students to watch your face, not your hands.
Teach A–M, N–Z chunks. Coach micro-pauses between letters in names to reduce blur.
Glow + Grow: one praise + one precise cue (e.g., 'GOOD. PALM IN. AGAIN.'). Keep turns ≤20–30s.

checksForUnderstanding.prompt: Show me M vs N silently
Partners: fix one orientation error you see

assessment.portfolioArtifact: Exit Ticket: 10–15s video spelling first/last name + 1 tech word

rubric.mastery: Consistent, precise handshapes across all letters

rubric.beginning: Often incorrect; rotates away from target
rubric.proficient: Correct in most cases with quick self-corrections

rubric.mastery: Smooth continuous flow; compact space; controlled pace

assessment.fastGradeMode: Score only Orientation, Handshape, Fluency (3-point scale). Mark reteach if 2+ dimensions = Beginning
assessment.reteachFlagRule: If the same error repeats ≥3 times in one clip, schedule a 2-minute micro-reteach next session

quizAnswerKey.6: Varies: name hardest letter(s) and one improvement plan

commonErrors: S/E squeezed too tight causing tension
classroomManagement: Pairs face each other; both keep eyes on partner’s face
Equity move: Everyone records at least once before end

dataReporting.grantNotes: This lesson supports Perkins V communication competency, ESSA Title IV well-rounded education, and IDEA accessibility via UDL scaffolds. Include rubric distributions and artifact counts in quarterly reports.

teacherReflection: Which letters produced the most orientation errors (M/N, G/Q)?
Who needs a 2-minute micro-reteach next class?
Did Glow+Grow feedback stay at 1 cue only? If not, adjust protocol.
homeExtension: Record 20s: spell full name + two school words; aim for smooth transitions
Teach a family member 5 letters; reflect on which cue helped them most

compliance.ethicsLine: Respect privacy in video artifacts; obtain consent per school policy; no public posting without permission.
compliance.a11yNote: Provide side-angle examples and extra time as needed; prioritize clarity over speed.
